0: Prepare and process import and export documentation according to customs regulations, laws, or procedures.
Clear goods through customs and to their destinations for clients.
Pay, or arrange for payment of, taxes and duties on shipments.
Calculate duty and tariff payments owed on shipments.
Request or compile necessary import documentation, such as customs invoices, certificates of origin, and cargo-control documents.
Classify goods according to tariff coding system.
Stay abreast of changes in import or export laws or regulations by reading current literature, attending meetings or conferences, or conferring with colleagues.
Sign documents on behalf of clients, using powers of attorney.
Advise customers on import and export restrictions, tariff systems, insurance requirements, quotas, or other customs-related matters.
Post bonds for the products being imported or assist clients in obtaining bonds.
Quote duty and tax rates on goods to be imported, based on federal tariffs and excise taxes.
Arrange for transportation, warehousing, or product distribution of imported or exported products.
Monitor or trace the location of goods.
Confer with officials in various agencies to facilitate clearance of goods through customs and quarantine.
Inform importers and exporters of steps to reduce duties and taxes.
Obtain line releases for frequent shippers of low-risk commodities, high-volume entries, or multiple-container loads.
Provide advice on transportation options, types of carriers, or shipping routes.
Contract with freight forwarders for destination services.
Apply for tariff concessions or for duty drawbacks and other refunds.
Insure cargo against loss, damage, or pilferage.
Prepare papers for shippers to appeal duty charges.
1: Analyze training needs to develop new training programs or modify and improve existing programs.
Evaluate instructor performance and the effectiveness of training programs, providing recommendations for improvement.

Plan, develop, and provide training and staff development programs, using knowledge of the effectiveness of methods such as classroom training, demonstrations, on-the-job training, meetings, conferences, and workshops.
Confer with management and conduct surveys to identify training needs based on projected production processes, changes, and other factors.
Conduct orientation sessions and arrange on-the-job training for new hires.
Train instructors and supervisors in techniques and skills for training and dealing with employees.
Develop and organize training manuals, multimedia visual aids, and other educational materials.
Prepare training budget for department or organization.
Develop testing and evaluation procedures.
Conduct or arrange for ongoing technical training and personal development classes for staff members.
Review and evaluate training and apprenticeship programs for compliance with government standards.
2: Monitor and record food temperatures to ensure food safety.
Cook foodstuffs according to menus, special dietary or nutritional restrictions, or numbers of portions to be served.
Rotate and store food supplies.
Wash pots, pans, dishes, utensils, or other cooking equipment.
Apportion and serve food to facility residents, employees, or patrons.
Clean and inspect galley equipment, kitchen appliances, and work areas to ensure cleanliness and functional operation.
Clean, cut, and cook meat, fish, or poultry.
Direct activities of one or more workers who assist in preparing and serving meals.
Train new employees.
Take inventory of supplies and equipment.
Requisition food supplies, kitchen equipment, and appliances, based on estimates of future needs.
Bake breads, rolls, or other pastries.

0: Prepare and submit shipment documentation to facilitate smooth clearance through customs.
Conduct research on export regulations, quotas, and restrictions to ensure compliance with relevant laws and regulations.
Negotiate with freight forwarders, carriers, and other stakeholders to resolve disputes and improve shipping efficiency.
Obtain necessary permits, licenses, and certifications required for international trade.
Verify the authenticity and accuracy of commercial invoices, certificates of origin, and other supporting documents.
Provide guidance on customs procedures, regulations, and best practices to clients and internal teams.
Develop and maintain relationships with government officials, regulatory agencies, and industry partners to stay informed about changing regulations and market trends.
Process and submit necessary paperwork for duty payments, taxes, and other charges associated with imported goods.
Coordinate with customs authorities to resolve clearance issues, discrepancies, or penalties related to shipments.
Create and manage client profiles, including documentation and communication history, to provide tailored support and service.
Monitor shipment status, track cargo, and alert clients to any changes or updates through regular reporting and updates.
Conduct compliance audits to identify areas for improvement and ensure adherence to relevant regulations and company policies.
Prepare and submit claims for lost, damaged, or stolen shipments to facilitate reimbursement and resolution.
Stay up-to-date with industry developments, regulatory changes, and market trends by attending training sessions and conferences.
Provide translation services for non-English documentation as needed to ensure effective communication with clients and stakeholders.
Manage and maintain accurate records of shipments, customs clearance, and other relevant data for audit and compliance purposes.
Act as liaison between shipping lines, carriers, and clients to resolve issues and improve the overall shipping experience.
Develop and implement new procedures, protocols, or systems to increase efficiency and reduce costs within the company.
Provide emergency support and assistance to clients in situations such as clearance delays, lost shipments, or other crises.
Maintain confidentiality and handle sensitive client information in accordance with company policies and regulations.
Develop and implement strategies to mitigate risks associated with international trade, including compliance, security, and insurance concerns.
1: Design and develop training programs for employees to improve job performance and organizational skills.
Assess employee training needs and create customized learning plans to meet business objectives.
Develop and implement a corporate training budget to optimize resource allocation and achieve business outcomes.
Collaborate with subject matter experts to design and deliver instructor-led training sessions, workshops, and webinars.
Coordinate logistics for in-person and online training events, including venue selection, catering, and technical requirements.
Evaluate the effectiveness of training programs using metrics such as participant engagement, knowledge retention, and job performance improvements.
Conduct needs analysis to identify areas for improvement and create a strategic learning plan aligned with organizational goals.
Develop and maintain a library of digital learning resources, including e-learning modules, videos, and online courses.
Create engaging training content, such as presentations, handouts, and assessments, using adult learning principles and instructional design best practices.
Identify opportunities for cross-functional training to enhance collaboration and knowledge sharing across departments and levels within the organization.
Facilitate mentoring programs to pair experienced employees with newer team members to facilitate knowledge transfer and skill development.
2: Prepare and cook meals according to nutritional standards and menu plans.
Maintain a clean and hygienic kitchen environment, adhering to health and safety regulations.
Operate cooking equipment, including ovens, stoves, and dishwashers, efficiently and safely.
Replenish ingredients and supplies in storage areas to ensure continuous service.
Clean and sanitize food preparation surfaces, utensils, and equipment after each use.
Assist with inventory management by tracking ingredient quantities and ordering supplies as needed.
Monitor food temperatures and presentation to ensure high-quality meals are served.
Follow institution/cafeteria policies and procedures for food handling, storage, and disposal.
Interact with patrons, colleagues, and management in a professional and courteous manner.
Restock condiments, drinks, and other beverages in dining areas and vending machines.
Troubleshoot kitchen equipment malfunctions and report issues to maintenance personnel promptly.
Participate in ongoing training and education to stay updated on culinary techniques, nutrition, and food safety standards.
